content.description: Start in the lichen-y corner, and stem/pull past two bolts into a pod. Place a medium nut or cam (or not?), and pull into the dihedral.  Use the finger pockets to move past two more bolts. Moving through and out of the dihedral is the crux of the route.  Clip a final bolt once you're out, and cruise to the anchor chains.
content.protection:
Five bolts with chain-anchors. A short section after the second bolt could use a medium nut or cam (~1 inch) to make getting into the dihedral a bit more secure (i.e., to remove the PG-13 rating).

Watch for some crumbly sections of rock down low. Everything else seems pretty solid.
content.location: It is on the smaller buttress just to the right of the gully, adjacent to the main formation. This is the only bolted route on this piece of rock.

content.description: R.O.U.S. is a great late afternoon winter climb due its brown rock and sun exposure.  Follow 4 bolts up a small spire with a handful of tricky moves and funky positions.  Short and sweet....
content.protection: Bolts, maybe a medium nut up high....
content.location: R.O.U.S. climbs the SW face of the small spire at the base of the cliffs.

content.description:
P1. Start on a dirty stance (with a much-needed anchor bolt), and climb up the arete left of the slab. There is an awkward crux down low, then the difficulty tapers off slightly; move right of the arete, and move into a secondary crux before reaching anchor chains at 100 feet.

P2. Belay from a very comfortable ledge.  Start right of the anchors and use the pocket to clip a high first bolt, sidepull, and cross over the arete into a dirty channel.  Move straight up into a gap and to the anchors, about 50 feet.
content.protection:
P1. 11 draws to two chain-anchors. There is a belay anchor at base of the climb down low.

P2. 4 (or 5?) draws to a double-bolt anchor with chains. Sling the 4th bolt for less drag.
content.location:
Approach as for

R.O.U.S.

; continue east and squeeze by a pine tree, being careful of the *very* loose rock. Traverse the dirty ledge, maybe 20 feet, to the belay station.

A double rope rap to the base of the climb is possible with two 60m ropes. One 70m rope comes up just short, but the downclimb seems possible, albeit slightly tenuous.  Alternately, do two raps to the first set of anchors then to the ground.

climbs.name: Prepare to Die
climbs.fa: unknown. Bernard Gillett and Doug Snively rediscovered in 2001

content.description: This is a striking leaning crack that begins in an alcove. This is overhanging and progressively widens as you head toward the corner. It will feel harder for those with small hands.
content.location: It is in the alcove between the main mass and the shorter buttress uphill.

content.description:
For the 5.10a variation, begin on the right side of the face, and climb up before moving more towards the center of the face about halfway up.

For the 5.10d variation, begin on the left side before moving to the center of the face just at the pine tree.

Both variations finish on easier rock to the anchor.
content.protection:
Set up a TR anchor on the chain-anchors for

Six Fingered Man

.
content.location:
These two TR variations share the small buttress with

Six Fingered Man

and are found on the face around the corner to the right of the bolt-line.  Rap the routes.

content.description:
Butter Cup climbs the SW face of the cliff to the top the arete climb, "

The Princess Tried

, 5.11b". The climbing has great position and exposure in the canyon. There are a handful of what do I do here moments but nothing too hard. End at a two bolt anchor on the left, and rap 90 feet to the ground. You will need to hike around the base to reach your packs.
content.location: Find a sunny alcove on the West side of the cliff above a small spire.  Butter Cup starts on a small ledge system to the left.

pathTokens: South Fork of St. Vrain Canyon
